Device Sampling and Resource Optimization for Federated Learning in Cooperative Edge Networks

Su Wang1, Roberto Morabito3, Seyyedali Hosseinalipour4, Mung Chiang1, and Christopher G. Brinton1
This work is an extension of our prior work titled â€œDevice sampling for heterogeneous federated learning: Theory, algorithms, and implementationâ€Â [1] published in the Proceedings of IEEE INFOCOM, 2021. 1School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Purdue University
3Department of Computer Science, University of Helsinki
4Department of Electrical Engineering, University at Buffaloâ€“SUNY
Email: 1{wang2506, chiang, cgb}@purdue.edu, 3roberto.morabito@helsinki.fi, 4alipour@buffalo.edu
Abstract

The conventional federated learning (FedL) architecture distributes machine learning (ML) across worker devices by having them train local models that are periodically aggregated by a server. FedL ignores two important characteristics of contemporary wireless networks, however: (i) the network may contain heterogeneous communication/computation resources, and (ii) there may be significant overlaps in devicesâ€™ local data distributions. In this work, we develop a novel optimization methodology that jointly accounts for these factors via intelligent device sampling complemented by device-to-device (D2D) offloading. Our optimization methodology aims to select the best combination of sampled nodes and data offloading configuration to maximize FedL training accuracy while minimizing data processing and D2D communication resource consumption subject to realistic constraints on the network topology and device capabilities. Theoretical analysis of the D2D offloading subproblem leads to new FedL convergence bounds and an efficient sequential convex optimizer. Using these results, we develop a sampling methodology based on graph convolutional networks (GCNs) which learns the relationship between network attributes, sampled nodes, and D2D data offloading to maximize FedL accuracy. Through evaluation on popular datasets and real-world network measurements from our edge testbed, we find that our methodology outperforms popular device sampling methodologies from literature in terms of ML model performance, data processing overhead, and energy consumption.

I Introduction

The proliferation of smartphones, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and other devices comprising the Internet of Things (IoT) is causing an exponential rise in data generation and large demands for machine learning (ML) at the edgeÂ [2, 3]. For example, sensor and camera modules on self-driving cars produce up to 1.4 terabytes of data per hourÂ [4] which enable the training of ML models for intelligent navigation and autonomous drivingÂ [5]. Unfortunately, traditional ML techniques where model training is conducted at a centralized server are not applicable to such distributed environments as the data often cannot be transferred to a server. There are two challenges in particular: (i) given the large volumes of data at the network edge, data transfer to a server imposes long delays and overloads the network infrastructureÂ [6], and (ii) in certain applications (such as healthcare), some users are unwilling to share their data owing to privacy concernsÂ [7].

Federated learning (FedL) has become a popular distributed ML technique aiming to overcome these challengesÂ [8, 9]. Under FedL, devices train models on their local datasets, typically by means of gradient descent, and a server periodically aggregates the parameters of local models to form a global model. These global model parameters are then transferred back to the devices for the next round of local updates, as depicted in Fig.Â 1. In standard FedL methodologies, each device processes its own collected data and operates independently within an aggregation periodÂ [10, 11]. This will, however, become problematic in terms of upstream device communication and local device processing requirements as implementations scale to networks consisting of millions of heterogeneous wireless devicesÂ [12, 13, 14].

At the same time, device-to-device (D2D) communications in cooperative 5G/IoT edge networks can enable consensual local offloading of data processing from resource hungry to resource rich devicesÂ [15, 16]. Additionally, we can expect that for particular applications, the datasets collected across devices will contain varying degrees of similarity, e.g., images gathered by UAVs surveying the same areaÂ [17, 18]. Processing similar data distributions at multiple devices adds unnecessary computational and communication overheads to FedL, thus leading to an opportunity for efficiency improvement.

Motivated by this, we develop a novel methodology for smart device sampling with data offloading in FedL. Specifically, we formulate a joint sampling and data offloading optimization problem where devices expected to maximize contribution to model training are sampled for training participation, while devices that are not selected may transfer data to devices that are. This data offloading is motivated by paradigms such as fog learningÂ [13, 19], in which data offloading only occurs among trusted devices; devices that have privacy concerns are exempt from data offloading. Furthermore, the data offloading is performed according to estimated data dissimilarities between nodes, which are updated as transfers occur. We show that our methodology yields comparable performance to conventional FedL, and superior performance relative to baselines from literature while significantly reducing network resource utilization.

I-A Related Work

Resource efficiency in federated learning Since conventional FedL in large-scale networks can incur heavy communication and computation resource use, many works have investigated avenues to reduce the resource burden of edge devices in FedL. In particular, a few popular and recent approaches have focused on efficient encoding designs to reduce parameter transmission sizesÂ [20, 21], optimizing the frequency of global aggregationsÂ [22, 23], and device sampling [24, 25, 26]. Our work falls into the device sampling category, in which methodologies rely on intelligent selection of devices for the global aggregation stage of FedL to improve resource efficiency. In this regard, most works have assumed a static or uniform device selection strategy, e.g.,Â [23, 27, 28, 9, 29, 30, 24], where the main server chooses a subset of devices either uniformly at random or according to a pre-determined sampling distribution.

While there are many different approaches for device sampling for FedL such as sampling based on wireless channel characteristics in cellular networks (e.g.,Â [31, 32, 33]), we focus on developing a sampling technique that adapts to the heterogeneity of device resources and the similarities/dissimilarities of data distributions across large-scale contemporary wireless edge networks. When investigating literature in this line of device sampling for FedL, popular works have attempted device sampling based on each deviceâ€™s instantaneous contributions to global updatesÂ [34], data proportional sampling based on devicesâ€™ local dataset sizesÂ [35, 25], and sampling devices based on local ML training lossÂ [36]. Specifically, when compared to the literature on device sampling by each deviceâ€™s instantaneous contributions to the global updatesÂ [34, 36], our proposed methodology introduces a novel perspective based on device data similarities, and furthermore exploits the proliferation of D2D cooperation at the wireless edgeÂ [37, 16, 38, 39] to diversify each selected deviceâ€™s local data via D2D offloading. Our work thus considers the problems of sampling and D2D offloading for FedL jointly, and leads to new analytical convergence bounds and algorithms used by implementations.

Towards further cooperation in federated learning. Most works in advancing conventional FedLÂ [28, 9, 40, 41] limit network cooperation to the global aggregation stages. While this is effective in situations requiring absolute data privacy, many practical large-scale and mobile edge networks are not limited to such an extentÂ [42, 43, 16]. Especially in large-scale and mobile edge networks, devices can be heterogeneous with respect to their data privacy demandsÂ [44, 45, 46]. While some devices may require absolute data privacy, many devices may be willing to share non-sensitive data or share all of their data to a device that they trust. Such is the case in recent literature on connected autonomous drivingÂ [47, 15], which rely on inter-device cooperation for normal functionality and is now attempting to integrate the benefits of modern ML. With this in mind, works such asÂ [44, 48, 49] have begun expanding the scope of cooperation in FedL. Specifically,Â [44] investigates FedL performance in the presence of D2D model offloading among edge devices,Â [48] proposes device to edge server data offloading so that edge servers can contribute to FedL training, andÂ [49] leverages D2D cooperation in edge networks to develop a modified version of SGD for FedL specifically. Our work contributes to existing literature in cooperative FedL by investigating how D2D data cooperation can lead to optimized device sampling with respect to ML training efficacy and total network resource consumption. Furthermore, our work assumes that devices are heterogeneous with respect to their privacy demands (i.e., they trust some edge devices but not others), resulting in some D2D links enabled and others disabled.

I-B Motivating Toy Example

Consider Fig.Â 2, wherein five heterogeneous connected vehicles communicate with an edge server to train an object detection model. Due to limited bandwidth, the server can only exploit 222 out of the 555 vehicles to conduct FedL training, but needs to train a model representative of the entire dataset within this network. The computational capability of each vehicle, i.e., the number of processed datapoints in one aggregation period, is shown next to the node representing the vehicle, and the edge weights in the data similarity graph capture the similarity between the local data of the vehicles. Rather than using statistical distance metricsÂ [50], which are hard to compute in this distributed scenario, the data similarities could be estimated by commute routes and geographical proximityÂ [51]. Also, in D2D-enabled environments, nodes can exchange small data samples with trusted neighbors to calculate similarities locally and report them to the server.

In Fig.Â 2, if the server samples the vehicles with the highest computational capabilities, i.e., Ağ´A and BğµB, the sampling is inefficient due to the high data similarity between them. Conversely, if it samples those with the lowest similarity, i.e., Dğ·D and Eğ¸E, the local models will be based on low computational capabilities, which will often result in a low accuracy (and could be catastrophic in this vehicular scenario). Optimal sampling of the vehicles considering both data similarities and computational capabilities is thus critical to the operation of FedL.

We take this one step further to consider how D2D offloading can lead to augmented local distributions of sampled vehicles. The node sampling must consider the neighborhoods of different vehicles and the capability of data offloading in those neighborhoods. For example, D2D is cheaper in terms of resource utilization among vehicles that are close in proximity. The feasible offloading topology shown in Fig.Â 2 is represented by the data offloading graph. Given Cğ¶Câ€™s high processing capability and data dissimilarity with neighboring vehicles Eğ¸E and Dğ·D, sampling Cğ¶C in a D2D-optimized solution combined with data offloading from Eğ¸E and Dğ·D to Cğ¶C can yield a composite of all three vehiclesâ€™ distributions. The purpose of this paper is to model these relationships for general edge/fog networks and optimize the resulting sampling and offloading configurations.

I-C Outline and Summary of Contributions

  • â€¢

    We formulate the joint sampling, D2D offloading, and communication and computation resource optimization problem for maximizing FedL model accuracy subject to realistic network constraints (Sec.Â II).

  • â€¢

    We develop an approach to D2D data similarity estimation by comparing the dataset centroids across network devices (Sec.Â II). This method enables the server to perform the optimization without harvesting actual device data.

  • â€¢

    Our theoretical analysis of the offloading subproblem for a fixed sampling strategy yields a new upper bound on the convergence of FedL under an arbitrary data sampling strategy (Sec.Â III). Using this bound, we derive an efficient sequential convex optimizer for the offloading strategy.

  • â€¢

    We propose a novel ML-based methodology that learns the desired combination of sampling and resulting offloading (Sec.Â IV). We encapsulate the network structure and offloading scheme into model features and learn a mapping to the sampling strategy that maximizes expected FedL accuracy.

  • â€¢

    We evaluate our methodology through experiments with network parameters obtained from our testbed of wireless IoT devices (Sec.Â V). Our methodology yields better ML accuracies and less resource consumption than recent device sampling baselines from literature.

  • â€¢

    We experimentally characterize our formulation by investigating its behavior with respect to various key optimization variables while varying network and sampling device set sizes (Sec.Â V).

II System and Optimization Model

II-C Distributed Machine Learning Model

The learning objective of FedL is to train a global ML model, parameterized by a vector ğ°âˆˆâ„pğ°superscriptâ„ğ‘\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{p} (e.g., pğ‘p weights in a neural network), by training at edge devices. Formally, for tâˆˆ{0,â‹¯,T}ğ‘¡0â‹¯ğ‘‡t\in\{0,\cdots,T\}, each sampled device iâˆˆğ’®ğ‘–ğ’®i\in\mathcal{S} is concerned with updating its model parameter vector ğ°iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{i}(t) on its local dataset ğ’Ÿiâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{i}(t). The local loss at device iâˆˆğ’©ğ‘–ğ’©i\in\mathcal{N} is defined as

Fâ€‹(ğ°iâ€‹(t)|ğ’Ÿiâ€‹(t))=âˆ‘dâˆˆğ’Ÿiâ€‹(t)fâ€‹(ğ°iâ€‹(t),ğ±d,yd)Diâ€‹(t),ğ¹conditionalsubscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ±ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘‘subscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘¡\displaystyle F(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t))=\frac{\sum_{d\in\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)}f(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t),\mathbf{x}_{d},y_{d})}{D_{i}(t)}, (5)

where fâ€‹(ğ°iâ€‹(t),xd,yd)ğ‘“subscriptğ°ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘‘f(\mathbf{w}_{i}(t),x_{d},y_{d}) denotes the corresponding loss (e.g., squared error for a regression problem, cross-entropy for a classification problemÂ [23]) of each datapoint dâˆˆğ’Ÿiğ‘‘subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–d\in\mathcal{D}_{i}. Each device minimizes its local loss sequentially via gradient descent:

The objective functionÂ (9) captures the balance between three key terms: the FedL loss inÂ (9)(a) scaled by Î±ğ›¼\alpha, the data processing resource use inÂ (9)(b) scaled by Î²ğ›½\beta, and the D2D offloading resource use inÂ (9)(c) scaled by Î³ğ›¾\gamma. The data at sampled devices, i.e., Diâ€‹(t)subscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘¡D_{i}(t) for iâˆˆğ’®ğ‘–ğ’®i\in\mathcal{S}, changes over time inÂ (10) based on the total received data Riâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘¡R_{i}(t) for device iğ‘–i. Riâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ‘¡R_{i}(t) is determined inÂ (11) by scaling the data transmissions from each device kâˆˆğ’®^ğ‘˜^ğ’®k\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} to device iğ‘–i according to the data similarity, which we explain further in the next paragraph. ThroughÂ (12)-(14), offloading only occurs between single-hop D2D neighbors from kâˆˆğ’®^ğ‘˜^ğ’®k\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} to iâˆˆğ’®ğ‘–ğ’®i\in\mathcal{S}, whileÂ (15) ensures that (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) maintains compliance with the desired sampling size, i.e., |ğ’®â‹†|=Ssuperscriptğ’®â‹†ğ‘†|\mathcal{S}^{\star}|=S. The two expressionsÂ (16)-(17) capture the definitions for Diâ€‹(t)subscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘¡D_{i}(t) and Î¦k,iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Phi_{k,i}(t). Next,Â (18) ensures that the total offload rate at each device cannot exceed the quantity of its local data clusters,Â (19) is the update rule for centroid differences between two clusters bğ‘b and cğ‘c at two difference devices iğ‘–i and kğ‘˜k, andÂ (20) clarifies that data offloading only occurs among the matched data clusters as described in Sec.Â II-B. The constraintsÂ (21)-(22) ensure that our D2D offloading solution adheres to maximum device data processing limits Piâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘¡P_{i}(t), and D2D communication limits Î¨iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ¨ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Psi_{i}(t). Finally,Â (23)-(24) express the lower and upper limits of the connectivity-similarity values and the data offloading variables.

Therefore, data offloading in ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} is conducted through a uniformly random selection of Î¦k,ib,câ€‹(t)â€‹Dkbâ€‹(tâˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘˜ğ‘ğ‘¡1\Phi_{k,i}^{b,c}(t)D_{k}^{b}(t-1) data points (for each data cluster bâˆˆğ’kğ‘subscriptğ’ğ‘˜b\in\mathcal{C}_{k}) from kğ‘˜k to send to iğ‘–i. We use the entirety of Î›k,iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ›ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Lambda_{k,i}(t) for this estimation because it is possible for data in cluster bğ‘b to have overlap with multiple clusters in ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–\mathcal{C}_{i} at device iğ‘–i. So, overall data similarity in the form of Î›k,iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ›ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Lambda_{k,i}(t) provides a better holistic estimate that an incoming data from device kğ‘˜k to iğ‘–i will be similar to any existing data at device iğ‘–i. Subsequently, we update Ïƒk,ib,câ€‹(t)superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡\sigma_{k,i}^{b,c}(t) perÂ (19) and then use the data similarity calculation inÂ (3) to update Î›k,iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ›ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Lambda_{k,i}(t). In particular, when kğ‘˜k transfers all of its data to iğ‘–i (i.e., when Î¦k,ib,câ€‹(t)=1superscriptsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘¡1\Phi_{k,i}^{b,c}(t)=1 âˆ€bâˆˆğ’kfor-allğ‘subscriptğ’ğ‘˜\forall b\in\mathcal{C}_{k}), Ïƒk,ib,c=0superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘0\sigma_{k,i}^{b,c}=0 âˆ€bâˆˆğ’kfor-allğ‘subscriptğ’ğ‘˜\forall b\in\mathcal{C}_{k} and âˆ€câˆˆğ’ifor-allğ‘subscriptğ’ğ‘–\forall c\in\mathcal{C}_{i}, leading to Î›k,iâ€‹(t)â†’0â†’subscriptÎ›ğ‘˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡0\Lambda_{k,i}(t)\rightarrow 0, thus preventing further data offloading according toÂ (11). Imposing these constraints promotes data diversity among the sampled nodes through offloading.

Solution overview: ProblemÂ ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} faces two major challenges: (i) it requires a concrete model of the loss function inÂ (9)(a) with respect to the datasets, which is, in general, intractable for deep learning modelsÂ [53], and (ii) even if the loss function is known, the coupled sampling and offloading procedures make this problem an NP-hard mixed integer programming problem. To overcome this, we will first consider the offloading subproblem for a fixed sampling strategy, and develop a sequential convex programming method to solve it in Sec.Â III. Then, we will integrate this into a graph convolutional network (GCN)-based methodology that learns the relationship between the network properties, sampling strategy (with its corresponding offloading), and the resulting FedL model accuracy in Sec.Â IV. An overall flowchart of our methodology is given in Fig.Â 3.

III Developing the Offloading Optimizer

In this section, we study the offloading optimization subproblem of ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}. Specifically, our theoretical analysis ofÂ (9)(a) under common assumptions will yield an efficient approximation of the FedL loss objective in terms of the offloading variables (Sec.Â III-B). We will then develop our solver for the resulting optimization (Sec.Â III-C).

III-A Definitions and Assumptions

To aid our theoretical analysis of FedL, similar to [23], we will consider a hypothetical ML training process that has access to the entire dataset ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(t)subscriptğ’Ÿğ’©ğ‘¡\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t) at each time instance. The parameter vector ğ¯kâ€‹(t)subscriptğ¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) for this centralized model is trained as follows: (i) at each global aggregation t=kâ€‹Ï„ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœt=k\tau, ğ¯kâ€‹(t)subscriptğ¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) is synchronized with ğ°ğ’®â€‹(t)subscriptğ°ğ’®ğ‘¡\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t), i.e., ğ¯kâ€‹(t)â†ğ°ğ’®â€‹(t)â†subscriptğ¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ°ğ’®ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)\leftarrow\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t), and (ii) in-between global aggregation periods, ğ¯kâ€‹(t)subscriptğ¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\mathbf{v}_{k}(t) is trained based on gradient descent iterations to minimize the global loss Fâ€‹(ğ¯kâ€‹(t)|ğ’Ÿğ’©â€‹(t))ğ¹conditionalsubscriptğ¯ğ‘˜ğ‘¡subscriptğ’Ÿğ’©ğ‘¡F(\mathbf{v}_{k}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{\mathcal{N}}(t)).

Despite these assumptions, we will show in Sec.Â V that our results still obtain significant improvements in practice for neural networks which do not obey the above assumptions.

III-B Upper Bound on Convergence

For convergence analysis, we assume that devices only offload the same data once, and assume that recipient nodes always keep received data. This must be done to ensure that the optimal global model parameters remain constant throughout time. III-C Offloading as a Sequential Convex Optimization

Using the result ofÂ (30) to replace the RHS ofÂ (29) implies that the FedL loss term in the objective function (i.e.,Â (9)(a)) is proportional to 1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=1TÎ´ğ’®â€‹(t)1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ›¿ğ’®ğ‘¡\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t), where Î´ğ’®â€‹(t)subscriptğ›¿ğ’®ğ‘¡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t) is defined inÂ (28) as a sum-of-ratios of Î´iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘¡\delta_{i}(t). Considering 1Tâ€‹âˆ‘t=1TÎ´ğ’®â€‹(t)1ğ‘‡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ›¿ğ’®ğ‘¡\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t) as the objective in problem ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}} yields the sum-of-ratios problem in fractional programmingÂ [54]. The scale of existing solvers for the sum-of-ratios fractional programming problem (e.g. [55]) are on the order of ten ratios, which corresponds to ten devices in our case. Contemporary large-scale networks that may have hundreds of edge devicesÂ [2] therefore cannot be solved accurately or in a time-sensitive manner. Motivated by the above fact, we approximate Î´ğ’®â€‹(t)â‰ˆ1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®Î´iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ›¿ğ’®ğ‘¡1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–ğ’®subscriptğ›¿ğ‘–ğ‘¡\delta_{\mathcal{S}}(t)\approx\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}}\delta_{i}(t). Using this withÂ (31), we obtain the following approximation forÂ (9):

Sequential gradient approximation: Obtaining âˆ‡Fâ€‹(t)Â¯Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¡\overline{\nabla F(t)} requires the knowledge of real-time gradients, âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°ğ’®â€‹(t)|ğ’Ÿiâ€‹(t))âˆ‡ğ¹conditionalsubscriptğ°ğ’®ğ‘¡subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(t)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(t)), âˆ€iâˆˆğ’®for-allğ‘–ğ’®\forall i\in\mathcal{S}, which are unknown a priori. Furthermore, the gradients of the devices are only observed at the global aggregation time instances t=kâ€‹Ï„ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœt=k\tau. Motivated by this, we approximate âˆ‡Fâ€‹(t)Â¯Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¡\overline{\nabla{{F}(t)}} for tâˆˆ{kâ€‹Ï„+1,â‹¯,(k+1)â€‹Ï„}ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœ1â‹¯ğ‘˜1ğœt\in\{k\tau+1,\cdots,(k+1)\tau\}, kâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,K}ğ‘˜1â‹¯ğ¾k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, using the gradients observed at the most recent global aggregation, i.e., âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ°ğ’®â€‹(kâ€‹Ï„)|ğ’Ÿiâ€‹(kâ€‹Ï„))âˆ‡ğ¹conditionalsubscriptğ°ğ’®ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–ğ‘˜ğœ\nabla F(\mathbf{w}_{\mathcal{S}}(k\tau)|\mathcal{D}_{i}(k\tau)), iâˆˆğ’®ğ‘–ğ’®i\in\mathcal{S} on which we perform a sequence of corrective approximations. Specifically, since the average loss Fğ¹F is convex, âˆ‡Fâ€‹(t)Â¯Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¡\overline{\nabla F(t)} is expected to decrease over time. We assume that this decrease occurs linearly and approximate the real-time gradient using the previously observed gradient at the server as âˆ‡Fâ€‹(t)Â¯â‰ˆâˆ‡Fâ€‹(kâ€‹Ï„)Â¯/Î±k+1tâˆ’kâ€‹Ï„Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¡Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘˜ğœsubscriptsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœğ‘˜1\overline{\nabla F(t)}\approx\overline{\nabla F(k\tau)}/{\alpha^{t-k\tau}_{k+1}}, tâˆˆ{kâ€‹Ï„+1,â‹¯,(k+1)â€‹Ï„}ğ‘¡ğ‘˜ğœ1â‹¯ğ‘˜1ğœt\in\{k\tau+1,\cdots,(k+1)\tau\}, âˆ€kâˆˆ{1,â‹¯,K}for-allğ‘˜1â‹¯ğ¾\forall k\in\{1,\cdots,K\}, where the scaling factor Î±k+1>1subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜11\alpha_{k+1}>1 is re-adjusted after every global aggregation kğ‘˜k. Through the re-adjustment procedure, the server receives the gradients and computes the scaling factor for the each aggregation period as Î±k+1=âˆ‡Fâ€‹((kâˆ’1)â€‹Ï„)Â¯/âˆ‡Fâ€‹(kâ€‹Ï„)Â¯Ï„subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1ğœÂ¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘˜1ğœÂ¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘˜ğœ\alpha_{k+1}=\sqrt[\tau]{\overline{\nabla F((k-1)\tau)}/\overline{\nabla F(k\tau)}}.

Given the aforementioned characteristics of terms (a)ğ‘(a) and (b)ğ‘(b) inÂ (33), our proposed iterative approximation of âˆ‡Fâ€‹(t)Â¯Â¯âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¡\overline{\nabla F(t)}, and the fact that the constraints of ğ“ŸDsubscriptğ“Ÿğ·\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D} are all affine at each time instance, we can solve this problem as a sequence of convex optimization problems over time. For this, we employ the CVXPY convex optimization software [56].

IV Smart Device Sampling with D2D Offloading

We now turn to the sampling decisions in problem ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}, which must be coupled with the offloading solution to ğ“ŸDsubscriptğ“Ÿğ·\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D}. After explaining the rationale for our GCN-based approach (Sec.Â IV-A), we will detail our training procedure encoding the network characteristics (Sec.Â IV-B). Finally, we will develop an iterative procedure for selecting the sample set (Sec.Â IV-C).

IV-A Rationale and Overview of GCN Sampling Approach

Sampling the optimal subset of nodes from a resource-constrained network to maximize a utility function (in our case, minimizing the ML loss) has some similarity to 0-1 knapsack problemÂ [57]. In this combinatorial optimization problem, a set of weights and values for nğ‘›n items are given, where each item can be either added or left out to maximize the value of the items within the knapsack subject to a weight capacity. Analogously, our sampling problem aims to maximize FedL accuracy while adhering to a sampling budget S=âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’©xiğ‘†subscriptğ‘–ğ’©subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–S=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}x_{i}. Strategies for the knapsack problem become unsuitable here because the value that each device provides to FedL is difficult to quantify: it depends on the ML loss function, the gradient descent procedure, and the D2D relationships from Sec.Â III.

To address these complexities, we propose a (separate) ML technique to model the relationship between network characteristics, the sampling set, and the resulting FedL model quality. Specifically, we develop a sampling technique based on active filtering of a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN)Â [58]. In a GCN, the learning procedure consists of sequentially feeding an input (the network graph) through a series of graph convolutionÂ [59] layers, which generalize the traditional convolution operation into non-Euclidean spaces and thus captures connections among nodes in different neighborhoods.

Our methodology is depicted in Fig.Â 5. GCNs excel at graph-based classification tasks, as they learn over the intrinsic graph structure. However, GCNs by themselves have performance issues when there are multiple good candidates for the classification problemÂ [60]. This holds for our large-scale network scenario, as many high performing sets of sampling candidates can be expected. The data offloading scheme adds another important dimension: a sampled node iğ‘–i may perform poorly when considered in isolation, but it may have high processing capacities Piâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘¡P_{i}(t) and be connected to unsampled nodes jâˆˆğ’®^ğ‘—^ğ’®j\in\hat{\mathcal{S}} with large quantities of local data and high transfer limits Î¨j,iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ¨ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Psi_{j,i}(t). We address these issues by (i) incorporating the solution from Sec.Â III into the GCN training procedure, and (ii) proposing sampling GCN-branch, a network-based post-processing technique that maps the GCN output to a sampling set by considering the underlying connectivity-similarity matrix.

IV-B GCN Architecture and Training Procedure

We consider a GCN function Hâ€‹(ğ…,ğ€~)ğ»ğ…~ğ€H(\boldsymbol{\pi},\tilde{\mathbf{A}}) with two inputs: (i)Â ğ…âˆˆâ„NÃ—Uğ…superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘ˆ\boldsymbol{\pi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times U}, a matrix of Uğ‘ˆU node features, and (ii) ğ€~âˆˆâ„NÃ—N~ğ€superscriptâ„ğ‘ğ‘\mathbf{\tilde{A}}\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times N}, the augmented connectivity-similarity matrix. The feature vector for each node iğ‘–i is defined as ğ…iâ‰œ[Diâ€‹(0),Piâ€‹(0),piâ€‹(0),Î¸iâ€‹(0)]â‰œsubscriptğ…ğ‘–subscriptğ·ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0subscriptğœƒğ‘–0\boldsymbol{\pi}_{i}\triangleq[D_{i}(0),P_{i}(0),p_{i}(0),\theta_{i}(0)], forming the rows of ğ…ğ…\boldsymbol{\pi}, and the augmented connectivity-similarity matrix is defined as ğ€~â‰œğš²â€‹(ğŸ)+ğˆNâ‰œ~ğ€ğš²0subscriptğˆğ‘\tilde{\mathbf{A}}\triangleq\boldsymbol{{\Lambda}(0)}+\mathbf{I}_{N}, where ğˆNsubscriptğˆğ‘\mathbf{I}_{N} denotes the identity matrixÂ [59]. As the number of devices Nğ‘N increases, the number of choices that will be considered for the sampled set increases combinatorially as (NS)binomialğ‘ğ‘†\binom{N}{S}. An advantage of this GCN procedure is that it can be adapted to networks of varying size: once trained on a set of realizations for tolerable-sized values of Nğ‘N, the graph convolutional layer weights ğ(l)superscriptğğ‘™\mathbf{Q}^{(l)}, lâˆˆ{1,2}ğ‘™12l\in\{1,2\}, can be applied to the desired network of varying size by shifting through the graph. Our obtained performance results in Sec.Â V verify this experimentally.

IV-C Offloading-Aware Smart Device Sampling

Given any network graph, our procedure must solve the sampling problem at the point of FedL initialization, i.e., t=0ğ‘¡0t=0. With the trained GCN in hand, we obtain ğ…ğ…\boldsymbol{\pi} and ğ€~~ğ€\tilde{\mathbf{A}} for the target network and calculate ğšª=Hâ€‹(ğ…,ğ€~)ğšªğ»ğ…~ğ€\boldsymbol{\Gamma}=H(\boldsymbol{\pi},\tilde{\mathbf{A}}), ğšª=[Î“i]1â‰¤iâ‰¤Nğšªsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptÎ“ğ‘–1ğ‘–ğ‘\boldsymbol{\Gamma}=[\Gamma_{i}]_{1\leq i\leq N}. Given this output, our sampling GCN-branch algorithm populates the set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} as follows. Let ğ’©pâŠ‚ğ’©subscriptğ’©ğ‘ğ’©\mathcal{N}_{p}\subset\mathcal{N} be the subset of nodes in the 95th percentile of initial data quantity. Starting with ğ’®=âˆ…ğ’®\mathcal{S}=\varnothing, the first node is added according to S=Sâˆª{s1}ğ‘†ğ‘†subscriptğ‘ 1S=S\cup\{s_{1}\}, where s1=argâ€‹maxiâˆˆğ’©pâ¡Î“isubscriptğ‘ 1subscriptargmaxğ‘–subscriptğ’©ğ‘subscriptÎ“ğ‘–s_{1}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{i\in\mathcal{N}_{p}}\Gamma_{i}. In this way, the first node added is the device with highest GCN probability among the largest data generation nodes. To choose subsequent sampled nodes, the algorithm performs a recursive branch-based search on the initial connectivity-similarity matrix ğš²â€‹(0)ğš²0\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(0) for nodes with the highest sampling probabilities and the smallest aggregate data similarity, as measured by maximin centroid difference, to the previously sampled nodes. Formally, we choose the nğ‘›n-th node addition as ğ’®=ğ’®âˆª{sn}ğ’®ğ’®subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›\mathcal{S}=\mathcal{S}\cup\{s_{n}\}, where sn=argâ€‹maxiâˆˆâ„›snâˆ’1â¡Î“isubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›subscriptargmaxğ‘–subscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1subscriptÎ“ğ‘–s_{n}=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{i\in\mathcal{R}_{s_{n-1}}}\Gamma_{i} with â„›snâˆ’1subscriptâ„›subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1\mathcal{R}_{s_{n-1}} denoting the neighbor nodes of snâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1s_{n-1} within the 95th percentile of link dissimilarity to snâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›1s_{n-1} (i.e., based on ğš²â€‹(0)ğš²0\boldsymbol{\Lambda}(0)) and the 80th percentile of maximin centroid difference relative to all the nodes in ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} thus far. In this way, our branch algorithm relies on the GCN to decide which branch the sampling scheme will follow given its current sampled nodes (visualization in Fig.Â 5), so that subsequent selections are more likely to contain nodes with (i) different data distributions while (ii) leading to new neighborhoods that can contribute to the current set. Once the sampled set ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} is determined, the offloading is scheduled for t=0,â€¦,Tğ‘¡0â€¦ğ‘‡t=0,...,T per the solver for ğ“ŸDsubscriptğ“Ÿğ·\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}_{D} from Sec.Â III.

Summary of methodology: Fig.Â 3 summarizes our methodology developed in Sec.Â III&IV for solving ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}. The sequential convex optimization for offloading (Sec.Â III) is embedded within the GCN-based sampling procedure (Sec.Â IV). Once the model is trained on sample network realizations, it is applied to the target network to generate the ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} and ğš½â€‹(t)ğš½ğ‘¡\boldsymbol{\Phi}(t) for FedL.

V Experimental Evaluation

V-A Setup and Experimental Procedure

V-A1 Network characteristics via wireless testbed

We employed our IoT testbed in Fig.Â 4 to obtain device and communication characteristics. It consists of Jetson Nano, Coral Dev Board TPU, and UP Squared AI Edge boards configured to operate in D2D mode. We used DstatÂ [61] to collect the device resources and power consumption. We map the measured computing resources (in CPU cycles and RAM) and the corresponding power consumption (in mW) at devices to the costs and capacities in our model by calculating the Gateway Performance Efficiency Factor (GPEF)Â [52]. Specifically, to determine the processing costs piâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘¡p_{i}(t), we measured the GPEF of the devices running gradient iterations on the MNIST datasetÂ [62]. For the processing capacities Piâ€‹(t)subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘–ğ‘¡P_{i}(t), we pushed the devices to 100% load and measured the GPEF. We initialized the devices at 25%-75% loads, and treated the available remaining capacity as the receive buffer parameter Î¸iâ€‹(t)subscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘¡\theta_{i}(t).

For the transmission costs, we measured GPEF spent on D2D offloading over WiFi. Our WiFi links, when only devoted to D2D offloading, consistently saturated at 12 Mbps. To simulate the effect of external tasks, we limit available bandwidth for D2D to 1, 6, and 9 Mbps. We then calculated the transmission resource budget for devices as transfer limits Î¨iâ€‹(t)subscriptÎ¨ğ‘–ğ‘¡\Psi_{i}(t), and modelled unit transfer costs Ïˆi,jâ€‹(t)subscriptğœ“ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\psi_{i,j}(t) as normalized D2D latency.

V-A2 Datasets and large-scale network generation

For FedL training, we use MNIST and Fashion-MNIST (F-MNIST)Â [63] image classification datasets. We consider a CNN predictor composed of two convolutional layers with ReLU activation and dropout. The devices perform Ï„=5ğœ5\tau=5 rounds of gradient descent with a learning rate Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01. Following [38], we generate network topologies with N=100ğ‘100N=100 to 800800800 devices using ErdÃ¶sâ€“RÃ©nyi graphs with link formation probability (i.e., Ai,j=1subscriptğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—1A_{i,j}=1) of 0.10.10.1. To produce local datasets across the nodes that are both overlapping and non-i.i.d, the datapoints at each node are chosen uniformly at random with replacement from datapoints among three labels (i.e., image classes). Differentiating the labels between devices captures dataset heterogeneity (i.e., from different devices collecting data from different labels). The number of initial datapoints Diâ€‹(0)subscriptğ·ğ‘–0D_{i}(0) at each device follows a normal distribution with mean Î¼=(Dğ’©â€‹(0))â€‹Nâˆ’1ğœ‡subscriptğ·ğ’©0superscriptğ‘1\mu=(D_{\mathcal{N}}(0))N^{-1} and variance Ïƒ2=0.2â€‹Î¼superscriptğœ20.2ğœ‡\sigma^{2}=0.2\mu. We further estimate the initial similarity weights Î»i,jâ€‹(0)subscriptğœ†ğ‘–ğ‘—0\lambda_{i,j}(0) based on the procedure discussed in Sec.Â II-B.

For the GCN-based sampling procedure, we train the model on small network realizations of ten devices. We consider sampling budgets of S=3ğ‘†3S=3 to 666, with corresponding training samples Eğ¸E for each case. We save the resulting graph convolutional layer weights ğ(1)superscriptğ1\mathbf{Q}^{(1)} and ğ(2)superscriptğ2\mathbf{Q}^{(2)} for each choice of Sğ‘†S and reapply them on the larger target networks.

V-B Results and Discussion

In the following experiments, we compare our methodology to several baseline sampling and offloading schemes. The three sampling strategies considered are Ours, data proportional probabilities (DPP)Â [35, 25], and power-of-choice (PoC)Â [26]. DPP is a random device sampling technique based on the quantity of local data at network devices, with larger datasets incurring a higher probability of sampling for FedL aggregations. On the other hand, PoC is a sampling technique based on the instantaneous training losses across network devices, with larger losses equating to a higher probability of being part of the sampled device set. Each of the three sampling schemes is investigated both with and without data offloading. For our sampling methodology, we employ our corresponding data offloading methodology. For both DPP and PoC sampling methodologies, we perform a greedy offloading that minimizes the communication resource costs while maintaining the same nominal offloaded data quantity as our methodology. A baseline of FedL with no sampling (i.e., all nodes active) and no offloading is also included.

V-B1 Model accuracy

Figs.Â 6 andÂ 7 show FedL accuracy for different sampling baselines on two popular ML datasets in six different combinations (S=3,4,5ğ‘†345S=3,4,5 and N=100,200ğ‘100200N=100,200), for these experiments we used Î³=0.01ğ›¾0.01\gamma=0.01 on MNIST and Î³=0.0045ğ›¾0.0045\gamma=0.0045 on FMNIST (both experiments used Î±=100ğ›¼100\alpha=100 and Î²=0.001ğ›½0.001\beta=0.001).111These values of Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Î²ğ›½\beta, and Î³ğ›¾\gamma enable the three objective function terms of (ğ“Ÿğ“Ÿ\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}), shown inÂ (9), to all have the same order of magnitude, i.e., ğ’ªâ€‹(102)ğ’ªsuperscript102\mathcal{O}(10^{2}). For the experiments involving data offloading, Ours w/ offloading consistently demonstrates at least a 5%percent55\% accuracy improvement over the baseline methodologies for MNIST (Fig.Â 6) with a maximum of 10%percent1010\% accuracy improvement in Fig.Â 6a). Similarly on F-MNIST (Fig.Â 7), our methodology is able to continue outperforming the baseline sampling methodologies for various Sğ‘†S and Nğ‘N combinations. The final accuracy attained by Ours w/ offloading is even able to match or outperform FedL all nodes in some cases. Our joint sampling and data offloading methodology is able to achieve better performance due to two main reasons: (i) it minimizes the data skew resulting from unbalanced label frequencies, and (ii) it ensures higher quality of local datasets at sampled nodes, which reduces bias caused by multiple local gradient descents. Without offloading, our sampling methodology is also able to either outperform or match the accuracies obtained by the DPP and PoC sampling strategies. Additionally, our method with offloading is able to offer consistent improvements over sampling without offloading in most cases, whereas the effects of data offloading are smaller or even detrimental for the baseline methodologies. This emphasizes the importance of designing the sampling and offloading schemes for FedL jointly.

V-B2 Model convergence speed

We next compare the convergence speeds of our methodology to the other schemes in terms of the number of global aggregations needed to reach specific accuracy thresholds. TableÂ I compares the convergence speeds on MNIST (to reach 69%) and F-MNIST (to reach 46%), respectively, for N=600,700,800ğ‘600700800N=600,700,800 and S=6ğ‘†6S=6, and uses a horizontal line to indicate when a methodology is unable to reach the specific accuracy thresholds. We investigate sampling methodologies with and without data offloading.

For methodologies involving data offloading, our method obtains the fastest convergences rates by far. Specifically, our method is at least 38% and 69% faster than the other baselines on MNIST and F-MNIST respectively. Furthermore, our method is only one to consistently be able to reach the accuracy thresholds. For example, while the baseline PoC w/ offload is able to reach the threshold for MNIST with N=700ğ‘700N=700, it fails to do for N=600ğ‘600N=600 and N=800ğ‘800N=800 on the same dataset.

Even without data offloading, our sampling methodology is still able to consistently reach the accuracy thresholds for both MNIST and F-MNIST. By contrast, both DPP and PoC baselines are unable to consistently obtain the accuracy thresholds for F-MNIST. Overall, we see that our joint sampling and offloading methodology obtains faster training speeds than the other methods. Enabling offloading is also seen to improve the convergence speeds of each sampling scheme; in fact, without offloading, several baseline cases fail to reach the given percentage of the FedL baseline.

V-B3 Resource utilization

Finally, we compare the resource utilization for the different schemes in terms of the total data processed and energy used (measured by GPEF consumption) across a sampled set Sğ‘†S of 6 nodes in a network of N=700ğ‘700N=700 edge devices. Fig.Â 8 depicts the total data processed while Fig.Â 9 shows the corresponding energy costs in GPEF. Both figures compare the resource consumption (data processed or energy used) that sampling methodologies with and without offloading incur in order to reach specific accuracy thresholds on both MNIST and F-MNIST. We see that our sampling methodology (both with and without offloading) requires fewer data to be processed and thus results in less energy use relative to the baselines for various accuracy thresholds.

Specifically, on the processed data side (Fig.Â 8), Ours w/ offload processes the least amount of training data across all cases. As the reference accuracy level increases, our methodology consistently requires fewer datapoints compared to the other methods (roughly 60% fewer on average), emphasizing its ability to get the most value from each processed datum. This emphasizes the benefits of well-designed data offloading in reducing the computational burden across the network as a whole, which is especially valuable in IoT and mobile edge applications. Furthermore, Ours without offloading requires fewer processed data than all other methods under evaluation aside from Ours w/ offload, which highlights the resource efficiency of our sampling methodology on its own.

Our methodologies are able to maintain their advantages on the energy costs side (Fig.Â 9). Similar to Fig.Â 8, our methodology with and without data offloading incurs the least amount of energy use as measured in terms of GPEF. On average, our method uses roughly 50% less energy than the baseline methods. While Ours w/ offload processed the least amount of training data in Fig.Â 8, we see that the energy costs incurred by it are fairly similar to those total costs incurred by Ours without data offloading in Fig.Â 9. So even though Ours w/ offload may process fewer data and thus have a lower data processing cost, it seems that the data offloading costs incurred over D2D links balances out the energy savings from fewer processed data for our methodology.

These experiments demonstrate that our joint optimization method exceeds baseline performances in terms of model accuracy, convergence speed, and resource utilization. Next, we experimentally characterize the behavior of the optimization formulation (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) by investigating its responses over training iterations, and the two energy scaling variables, Î²ğ›½\beta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma.

V-B4 Optimization characterization

We characterize the behavior of our optimization formulation (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) in three key aspects: (i) its behavior over time as the FedL process converges, (ii) its sensitivity to the data processing energy use (scaled by Î²ğ›½\beta), and (iii) its responses to the data offloading energy use (scaled by Î³ğ›¾\gamma). For all of these experiments, we investigate on networks of Nâˆˆ{200,400,600,800}ğ‘200400600800N\in\{200,400,600,800\} nodes while sampling Sâˆˆ{3,5,7}ğ‘†357S\in\{3,5,7\} devices. In addition, these experiments all use Î±=100ğ›¼100\alpha=100, Î²=0.001ğ›½0.001\beta=0.001, and Î³=0.001ğ›¾0.001\gamma=0.001 unless stated otherwise.

First, we characterize the behavior of (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) with respect to training iterations in Fig.Â 10. Here, Fig.Â 10 highlights the average offloading rate at active links (i.e., links that have a non-zero data offloading rate). One of the major effects shown in Fig.Â 10 is device/link saturation, in which D2D links gradually cease to be used for data offloading. The main reason for this is that, over time, sampled devices gather enough data from nearby willing unsampled devices that they no longer have any remaining data processing capabilities (as described inÂ (21)). This effect becomes more noticeable as the edge network grows in size, which leads to more D2D connections from unsampled to sampled devices and thus faster device/link saturation. For instance in Fig.Â 10, the average data offloading rate at active D2D links rapidly decreases (in less than 10 iterations) from more than 0.80.80.8 to 00 for N=800ğ‘800N=800 regardless of sampled device set size, while for N=200ğ‘200N=200, the average data offloading rate requires roughly 20 iterations to approach 00 for all Sâˆˆ{3,5,7}ğ‘†357S\in\{3,5,7\}.

More D2D connections among devices also leads to higher initial average data offloading rates among active D2D links in Fig.Â 10. The two reasons for this are: (i) more links leads to more valuable data offloading opportunities and thereby more data offloading, and (ii) simulation setup in Sec.Â V-A2 in which the datasets for larger networks are initialized at smaller sizes in order to form a partition of the full ML dataset.

Next, we investigate the sensitivity of (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) to Î²ğ›½\beta in Fig.Â 11. As we vary Î²ğ›½\beta from 0.0010.0010.001 to 101010, the cost of processing data becomes more expensive relative to the FedL loss term in (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) andÂ (9). Initially, for small Î²ğ›½\beta in N=200ğ‘200N=200, the cost of processing data is essentially negligible and the average data processed is at a stable point until the Î²ğ›½\beta scaling reaches a point that is comparable in value to the FedL loss term inÂ (9). Further increases in Î²ğ›½\beta then lead to reductions in the average data processed per device until nearly no data is processed, and, correspondingly, the estimated and normalized FedL loss increases.

Fig.Â 11 also highlights some of the effects of large-scale networks and sampled device set size. Here, as the networks grow in size from 200200200 to 800800800 devices, we see that the average data processed per sampled device is increasing, specifically from under 200200200 data per device when N=200ğ‘200N=200 to over 400400400 data per device when N=800ğ‘800N=800. This is because larger networks have more links, and therefore more valuable data offloading, which leads to more D2D offloading and more data processed. On the other hand, as the sampled device set size increases from S=3ğ‘†3S=3 to S=7ğ‘†7S=7, the opposite effect occurs as the average data processed per sampled device decreases. More sampled devices not only leads to more D2D data offloading opportunities, but also enables the unsampled devices to spread out their data to more sampled devices. As a result, the burden of data processing can be shared among more sampled devices, thus leading to the decrease in average data processed per sampled device.

Finally, we observe the responsiveness of (ğ“Ÿ)ğ“Ÿ(\boldsymbol{\mathcal{P}}) to changes in the value of D2D offloading costs in Fig.Â 12 by measuring the change in average data offload quantity relative to Î³ğ›¾\gamma, the scaling of D2D offloading. As Î³ğ›¾\gamma increases from 0.000010.000010.00001 to 0.010.010.01, the cost of D2D data offloading becomes more expensive relative to the data processing and FedL cost terms fromÂ (9). Small Î³ğ›¾\gamma initially has little impact on average data offloading in small networks of N=200ğ‘200N=200 until the Î³ğ›¾\gamma scaling term makes the D2D communication cost comparable to that of the FedL performance term inÂ (9). Then average data offloading quantity rapidly decreases to 00 and correspondingly the normalized FedL term increases.

Fig.Â 12 provides two additional insights. First, as the network grows in size from N=200ğ‘200N=200 to N=800ğ‘800N=800, the average data offload quantity per D2D link remains quite stable, with all Fig.Â 12a)-Fig.Â 12d) demonstrating average data offload rates between 101010 to 202020 for Î³=0.00001ğ›¾0.00001\gamma=0.00001. That being said, larger networks do demonstrate hightened sensitivity to Î³ğ›¾\gamma. For example, for all Sâˆˆ{3,5,7}ğ‘†357S\in\{3,5,7\}, while the average data offloaded in a network with N=200ğ‘200N=200 remains stable for Î³âˆˆ[0.00001,0.001]ğ›¾0.000010.001\gamma\in[0.00001,0.001], the average data offloaded decreases more and more rapidly as the network size grows to 400400400, 600600600, and then 800800800 nodes for the same Î³ğ›¾\gamma range. The second is that as the sampled device set size increases from S=3ğ‘†3S=3 to S=7ğ‘†7S=7, the average data offloaded per D2D link increases. This is due to the existence of more D2D connections between unsampled and sampled devices, enabling more links to be active.

VI Conclusion and Future Work

In this paper, we developed a novel methodology to solve the joint sampling and D2D offloading optimization problem for FedL. Our theoretical analysis of the offloading subproblem produced new convergence bounds for FedL, and led to a sequential convex optimization solver. We then developed a GCN-based algorithm that determines the sampling strategy by learning the relationships between the network properties, the offloading topology, the sampling set, and the FedL accuracy. Our implementations using popular datasets and real-world IoT measurements from our testbed demonstrated that our methodology obtains significant improvements in terms of datapoints processed, training speed, and resulting model accuracy compared to several other algorithms, including FedL using all devices. Future investigations will consider the integration of further realistic network characteristics such as unlabeled dataÂ [64] on FedL.

Applying the triangle inequality on the above gives the result.
